# List of Arsenal F.C. records and statistics

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about all-time records. For a season-by-season statistical
breakdown, see [List of Arsenal F.C.
seasons](/wiki/List_of_Arsenal_F.C._seasons "List of Arsenal F.C. seasons").

[![Thierry Henry, wearing gloves and a redcurrant football shirt applauds the
crowd. A stand full with people and man wearing a football shirt are visible
in the
background.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bd/Thierry_Henry_Charlton.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thierry_Henry_Charlton.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Thierry_Henry_Charlton.jpg "Enlarge")

[Thierry Henry](/wiki/Thierry_Henry "Thierry Henry") became Arsenal's record
goalscorer in October 2005.

[Arsenal Football Club](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.") is an English
professional [association football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") club based in [Holloway, London](/wiki/Holloway,_London "Holloway,
London"). The club was formed in [Woolwich](/wiki/Woolwich "Woolwich") in 1886
as Dial Square before being renamed as Royal Arsenal, and then Woolwich
Arsenal in 1893.[1] In 1914, the club's name was shortened to Arsenal F.C.
after moving to [Highbury](/wiki/Arsenal_Stadium "Arsenal Stadium") a year
earlier.[2] After spending their first four seasons solely participating in
cup tournaments and [friendlies](/wiki/Friendly_match#Association_football
"Friendly match"), Arsenal became the first southern member admitted into [the
Football League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The Football League") in 1893.[3]
In spite of finishing fifth in the [Second
Division](/wiki/Football_League_Second_Division "Football League Second
Division") in 1919, the club was voted to rejoin the [First
Division](/wiki/Football_League_First_Division "Football League First
Division") at the expense of local rivals [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C.").[4] Since that
time, they have not fallen below the first tier of the [English football
league system](/wiki/English_football_league_system "English football league
system") and hold the record for the longest uninterrupted period in the top
flight.[5] The club remained in the Football League until 1992, when its First
Division was superseded as English football's top level by the newly formed
[Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League"), of which they were an
inaugural member.[6]

The list encompasses the honours won by Arsenal at national, regional, county
and friendly level, records set by the club, their managers and their players.
The player records section itemises the club's leading goalscorers and those
who have made most appearances in first-team competitions. It also records
notable achievements by Arsenal players on the international stage, and the
highest transfer fees paid and received by the club. Attendance records at
Highbury, the [Emirates Stadium](/wiki/Emirates_Stadium "Emirates Stadium"),
the club's home ground since 2006, and [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\) "Wembley Stadium \(1923\)"), their
temporary home for [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA
Champions League") games between 1998 and 1999, are also included.

Arsenal have won 13 top-flight titles, and also hold the record for the most
[FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup") wins, with 13. The club's record appearance
maker is [David O'Leary](/wiki/David_O%27Leary "David O'Leary"), who made 722
appearances between 1975 and 1993. [Thierry Henry](/wiki/Thierry_Henry
"Thierry Henry") is Arsenal's record goalscorer, scoring 228 goals in total.

All figures are correct as of the match played on 22 October 2017.

## Honours and
achievements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Honours and achievements")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/GoldInvinciblesTrophy.jpg/220px-
GoldInvinciblesTrophy.jpg)](/wiki/File:GoldInvinciblesTrophy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GoldInvinciblesTrophy.jpg "Enlarge")

After Arsenal completed the only 38-match season unbeaten, the [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") commissioned a unique gold
trophy to commemorate the achievement.

Arsenal's first ever silverware was won as the Royal Arsenal in 1890. The
[Kent Junior
Cup](/wiki/Kent_County_Football_Association#County_Cup_Competitions "Kent
County Football Association"), won by Royal Arsenal's reserves, was the club's
first trophy, while the first team's first trophy came three weeks later when
they won the [Kent Senior Cup](/wiki/Kent_Senior_Cup "Kent Senior Cup").[7][8]
Their first national senior honour came in 1930, when they won the [FA
Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup").[9] The club enjoyed further success in the 1930s,
winning another FA Cup and five [Football League First
Division](/wiki/Football_League_First_Division "Football League First
Division") titles.[10][11] Arsenal won their first league and cup
[double](/wiki/Double_\(association_football\)#England "Double \(association
football\)") in the [1970–71 season](/wiki/1970%E2%80%9371_in_English_football
"1970–71 in English football") and twice repeated the feat, in
[1997–98](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_in_English_football "1997–98 in English
football") and [2001–02](/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_in_English_football "2001–02 in
English football"), as well as winning a cup double of the FA Cup and [League
Cup](/wiki/Football_League_Cup "Football League Cup") in
[1992–93](/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_in_English_football "1992–93 in English
football").[12] In [2003–04](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_in_English_football
"2003–04 in English football"), Arsenal recorded an unbeaten top-flight league
season, something achieved only once before by [Preston North
End](/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C. "Preston North End F.C.") in
[1888–89](/wiki/1888%E2%80%9389_Football_League "1888–89 Football League"),
who only had to play 22 games.[13] To mark the achievement, a special gold
version of the Premier League trophy was commissioned and presented to the
club the following season.[14] Their most recent success came in 2017, when
they became the most successful club in FA Cup history with 13 titles.[15]

#### Top
goalscorers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Top goalscorers")]

Thierry Henry is the all-time top goalscorer for Arsenal. He passed [Ian
Wright](/wiki/Ian_Wright "Ian Wright")'s eight-year record after scoring twice
in a European tie against [Sparta Prague](/wiki/AC_Sparta_Prague "AC Sparta
Prague") in October 2005.[73] Henry was Arsenal's leading goalscorer for seven
consecutive seasons, from

F.C. season") to [2005–06](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Arsenal_F.C._season "2005–06

International[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: International")]

[![A black-and-white photograph of footballer Caesar Jenkyns, wearing a
vertically-stripped
shirt.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/CaesarJenkyns.jpg/180px-
CaesarJenkyns.jpg)](/wiki/File:CaesarJenkyns.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CaesarJenkyns.jpg "Enlarge")

[Caesar Jenkyns](/wiki/Caesar_Jenkyns "Caesar Jenkyns") was the first Arsenal
player to receive an international cap.

This section refers only to [caps](/wiki/Cap_\(sport\) "Cap \(sport\)") won
while an Arsenal player.

  * First capped player: [Caesar Jenkyns](/wiki/Caesar_Jenkyns "Caesar Jenkyns"), for [Wales](/wiki/Wales_national_football_team "Wales national football team") against [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland national football team") on 21 March 1896[77]
  * First capped player for [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football team"): [Jimmy Ashcroft](/wiki/Jimmy_Ashcroft "Jimmy Ashcroft"), against [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland_national_football_team_\(1882%E2%80%931950\) "Ireland national football team \(1882–1950\)") on 17 February 1906[78]
  * Most capped player: Thierry Henry with 81 caps[79]
  * Most capped player for England: [Kenny Sansom](/wiki/Kenny_Sansom "Kenny Sansom") with 77 caps[80]
  * First players to play in the [World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup") finals: [Dave Bowen](/wiki/Dave_Bowen "Dave Bowen") and [Jack Kelsey](/wiki/Jack_Kelsey "Jack Kelsey"), for Wales against [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary_national_football_team "Hungary national football team") on 8 June 1958[81]
  * First players to play in a World Cup for England:[d] [Graham Rix](/wiki/Graham_Rix "Graham Rix") and Kenny Sansom against [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team") on 16 June 1982[83]
  * Most players from one club in an England starting line-up: 7, against [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team") – the so-called "[Battle of Highbury](/wiki/Battle_of_Highbury "Battle of Highbury")" on 14 November 1934[84]
  * First player to play in a World Cup final: [Emmanuel Petit](/wiki/Emmanuel_Petit "Emmanuel Petit") for France against [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team") on 12 July 1998[85]
  * First players to win a World Cup winners' medal:[e] Emmanuel Petit and [Patrick Vieira](/wiki/Patrick_Vieira "Patrick Vieira") ([1998 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup"))[87]
  * First players to play in a [European Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship") final: Thierry Henry and Patrick Vieira for France against Italy on 2 July 2000[88]
  * First players to win a European Championship winners' medal: Thierry Henry, Emmanuel Petit and Patrick Vieira ([UEFA Euro 2000](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2000 "UEFA Euro 2000"))[88]
  * First player to win a Copa América winners' medal: [Alexis Sánchez](/wiki/Alexis_S%C3%A1nchez "Alexis Sánchez") ([2015 Copa América](/wiki/2015_Copa_Am%C3%A9rica "2015 Copa América"))

At 17 years and 75 days, [Theo Walcott](/wiki/Theo_Walcott "Theo Walcott")
became the youngest player to earn an England cap, against Hungary on 30 May
2006.[89]

#### Record consecutive
results[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Record consecutive results")]

Arsenal hold several [English football
records](/wiki/Football_records_in_England "Football records in England"),
including the longest unbeaten sequence in the top flight, with 49. In the
[2001–02](/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_FA_Premier_League "2001–02 FA Premier League")
season, en route to winning the title, the club had won their remaining 13
matches. A 2–0 win against [Birmingham City](/wiki/Birmingham_City_F.C.
"Birmingham City F.C.") in the first match of the following season meant
Arsenal broke the national record for the most consecutive league wins in the
top division.[116] Arsenal scored in all 55 league matches from between 19 May
2001 to 30 November 2002 and also hold the longest unbeaten away sequence in
league football with 27, from 5 April 2003 to 25 September 2004.[117]

  * Record consecutive wins: 14, from 12 September 1987 to 11 November 1987[115]
  * Record consecutive league wins: 14, from 10 February 2002 to 18 August 2002[111]
  * Record consecutive wins coming from behind: 4, from 11 February 2012 to 12 March 2012[118]
  * Record consecutive defeats: 8, from 12 February 1977 to 12 March 1977[115]
  * Record consecutive league defeats: 7, from 12 February 1977 to 12 March 1977[115]
  * Record consecutive draws: 6, from 3 March 1961 to 1 April 1961[115]
  * Record consecutive matches without a defeat: 28, from 9 April 2007 to 24 November 2007[115]
  * Record consecutive league matches without a defeat: 49, from [7 May 2003 to 16 October 2004](/wiki/The_Invincibles_\(football\)#Arsenal "The Invincibles \(football\)")[115]
  * Record consecutive matches without a win: 19, from 28 September 1912 to 15 January 1913[119]
  * Record consecutive league matches without a win: 23, from 28 September 1912 to 1 March 1913[115]

###
Goals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Goals")]

  * Most league goals scored in a season: 127 in 42 matches, First Division, [1930–31](/wiki/1930%E2%80%9331_Football_League "1930–31 Football League")[120]
  * Fewest league goals scored in a season: 26 in 38 matches, First Division, [1912–13](/wiki/1912%E2%80%9313_Football_League "1912–13 Football League")[121]
  * Most league goals conceded in a season: 86 in 42 matches, First Division, [1926–27](/wiki/1926%E2%80%9327_Football_League "1926–27 Football League") and [1927–28](/wiki/1927%E2%80%9328_Football_League "1927–28 Football League")[122]
  * Fewest league goals conceded in a season: 17 in 38 matches, Premier League, [1998–99](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_FA_Premier_League "1998–99 FA Premier League")[123]

###
Points[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Points")]

  * Most points in a season: 
    * Two points for a win: 66 in 42 matches, First Division, 1930–31[124]
    * Three points for a win: 90 in 38 matches, Premier League, 2003–04[125]
  * Fewest points in a season: 
    * Two points for a win: 18 in 38 matches, First Division, 1912–13[121]
    * Three points for a win: 51 in 42 matches, Premier League, [1994–95](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_FA_Premier_League "1994–95 FA Premier League")[126]

###
Attendances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Attendances")]

This section applies to attendances at [Highbury](/wiki/Arsenal_Stadium
"Arsenal Stadium"), where Arsenal played their home matches from 1913 to 2006,
the [Emirates Stadium](/wiki/Emirates_Stadium "Emirates Stadium"), the club's
present home, and [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\) "Wembley
Stadium \(1923\)"), which acted as Arsenal's home in the UEFA Champions League
during the 1998–99 and 1999–2000 seasons.[66] Arsenal's attendance figures
since the move to the Emirates Stadium have been measured by tickets
sold.[127]

  * Highest attendance at Highbury: 73,295, against Sunderland, First Division, 9 March 1935
  * Lowest attendance at Highbury: 4,554, against Leeds United, First Division, 5 May 1966
  * Highest attendance at the Emirates Stadium: 60,161, against [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C."), Premier League, 3 November 2007
  * Lowest attendance at the Emirates Stadium: 46,539, against [Shrewsbury Town](/wiki/Shrewsbury_Town_F.C. "Shrewsbury Town F.C."), League Cup third round, 20 September 2011
  * Highest attendance Wembley Stadium: 73,707, against [Lens](/wiki/RC_Lens "RC Lens"), UEFA Champions League group stage, 25 November 1998
  * Lowest attendance at Wembley Stadium: 71,227, against [AIK](/wiki/AIK_Fotboll "AIK Fotboll"), UEFA Champions League group stage, 22 September 1999

On 17 January 1948, a league-record attendance of 83,260 watched Manchester
United play Arsenal at [Maine Road](/wiki/Maine_Road "Maine Road").[128] All
of the top three attendances in league football occurred at Arsenal
games.[128]

## European
statistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: European statistics")]

Main article: [Arsenal F.C. in European
football](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C._in_European_football "Arsenal F.C. in European
football")

Arsenal have won two European honours: the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup in 1970 and
the Cup Winners' Cup in 1994. They also reached the final of the UEFA Cup in
[2000](/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final "2000 UEFA Cup Final"), and became the first
London team to appear in a UEFA Champions League final in
[2006](/wiki/2006_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2006 UEFA Champions League
Final").[129][130] Despite having never won the UEFA Champions League, Arsenal
have set numerous records in the competition. Between
[1998–99](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_UEFA_Champions_League "1998–99 UEFA Champions
League") and the current season,
[2016–17](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Champions_League "2016–17 UEFA Champions
League"), they participated in nineteen successive seasons, a record only
surpassed in Europe by [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid
C.F.").[131] Goalkeeper [Jens Lehmann](/wiki/Jens_Lehmann "Jens Lehmann") kept
ten consecutive clean sheets in the run-in to Arsenal's first UEFA Champions
League final and the defence went 995 minutes until conceding a goal.[132]
Arsenal were also the first British side to defeat Real Madrid and [Borussia
Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund "Borussia Dortmund") away from home, and
both Milanese teams: [Internazionale](/wiki/Inter_Milan "Inter Milan") and
[Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan") at the [San Siro](/wiki/San_Siro "San
Siro").[133]

Thierry Henry holds the club record for most appearances with 86, and is the
club's record goalscorer in European competitions with 42 goals.[66][71]

## Global
records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Arsenal_F.C._records_and_statistics&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Global records")]

In August 1928, Arsenal, alongside Chelsea, made history by becoming the first
football clubs to wear numbered shirts.[134] A year earlier the first ever
live radio commentary of a football match took place, between Arsenal and
Sheffield United.[135] Arsenal played in the first match broadcast live on
television, against their reserve counterparts in 1937 and have since
participated in the world's first live 3D and
[interactive](/wiki/Sky_Sports_Active "Sky Sports Active") football matches,
both with Manchester United.[136][137][138]
